page.title: 07DECOY HOUSE
page.content: Decoy House was built in 1660 and has two original Jacobean fireplaces. It used to belong to the Norfolk Estate. In the eighteenth century the water baliff paid an annual rent of twelve dozen ducks to Arundel Castle for banquets there. The ponds date back to the 1660's. Their purpose was to decoy ducks into landing so they could be snared. The Decoy House is now owned by a vetinary surgeon. The ponds were in use until about 1870. The ponds are used nowadays for licenced fishing. One of the small ponds was drained by New Place Farm, because they believed it to be the cause of a disease called ague, a type of malaria.
